Award.AwardTitle: Conformation and Alignment Control in Scalable Graphene Film Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the characterization and control of graphene dynamics during liquid-phase processing. Graphene has outstanding mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties with a wide range of electronic and aerospace applications. However, conformation (internal configuration) and alignment (orientation) have a strong influence on the practical properties of graphene-based films. This project combines simulations with experimental studies of graphene dynamics during film processing. Two approaches are utilized: (1) Brownian Dynamics/Particle Tracking simulations are utilized to model graphene conformation during various film processing flows. This technique simulates graphene conformation as a function of space and time in a pre-computed dynamic flow field. (2) The same flows are experimentally utilized to produce conductive graphene-based thin films and graphene/polymer composite films. The effects of processing flow type and strength are quantified on both macroscopic film properties and nanoscale graphene conformation and alignment. Graphene conformation is quantified as a function of stabilizer type and sonication energy.

If successful, these novel simulations and experiments will fill a critical need in the engineering community to provide fundamental scientific insight into the prediction, characterization, and control of graphene morphology in solution. The simulations and experiments identify the processing parameter space where flow forces promote the desired microstructure and properties for a given application; for instance, extensional flow forces can promote a flat, aligned graphene conformation for transparency and conductivity in thin films. This work has broad impacts for industrial processing techniques including (1) inkjet printing and roll-to-roll coating of transparent, conductive, thin films for use in electronics and (2) multifunctional nanocomposite coatings for reinforcement and sensing. These research tasks will be integrated with graduate and undergraduate education, with a heavy emphasis on curriculum development and independent undergraduate research training, in addition to outreach activities for undergraduates and K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Very little is known about the morphology dynamics of 2-D nanosheets (such as graphene) dispersed in solvents, despite the wealth of studies probing the mobility of 1-D nanomaterials and polymers in solvents. This is important because the morphology (crumpled, flat, or stretched) of such nanosheets has a direct impact on their properties in composites, electrodes, and thin film electronics.  For the first time, we have demonstrated that Brownian Dynamics (BD) simulations can capture the motion of these nanosheets on the timescales of typical processing flows. Our findings show that the out-of-plane bending stiffness of the nanomaterial is the main predictor of the nanomaterial’s response to applied shear or extensional flow. High-rigidity nanosheets are more prone to show the classical tumbling response in shear, while low-rigidity nanosheets may undergo a coil-stretch transition, similar to semiflexible polymers.

Our outcomes include both (1) the development of BD methodologies for simulating higher-dimensional nanomaterials and (2) specific findings for nanosheet responses to shear and extensional flow.

Finally, we were also able to compare these simulation results against experimental results for nanosheet hydrodynamic radius. In fact, the simulation results were able to account for how bending modulus impacts the extension of nanosheets in solution. This means that an experimental study of hydrodynamic radius varying with nanosheet size is a bulk means to probe nanoscale mechanical properties, which would vary with nanosheet composition and number of layers.

These results pave the way for design-guided nanosheet technology; for instance, knowledge of nanosheet crumpling and extension can allow engineers to selectively produce nanosheets either as crumpled, high-surface-area powders or as flat, coherent films.

 


Last Modified: 11/23/2016
Modified by: Micah J Green
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Very little is known about the morphology dynamics of 2-D nanosheets (such as graphene) dispersed in solvents, despite the wealth of studies probing the mobility of 1-D nanomaterials and polymers in solvents. This is important because the morphology (crumpled, flat, or stretched) of such nanosheets has a direct impact on their properties in composites, electrodes, and thin film electronics. For the first time, we have demonstrated that Brownian Dynamics (BD) simulations can capture the motion of these nanosheets on the timescales of typical processing flows. Our findings show that the out-of-plane bending stiffness of the nanomaterial is the main predictor of the nanomaterial?s response to applied shear or extensional flow. High-rigidity nanosheets are more prone to show the classical tumbling response in shear, while low-rigidity nanosheets may undergo a coil-stretch transition, similar to semiflexible polymers. Our outcomes include both (1) the development of BD methodologies for simulating higher-dimensional nanomaterials and (2) specific findings for nanosheet responses to shear and extensional flow. Finally, we were also able to compare these simulation results against experimental results for nanosheet hydrodynamic radius. In fact, the simulation results were able to account for how bending modulus impacts the extension of nanosheets in solution. This means that an experimental study of hydrodynamic radius varying with nanosheet size is a bulk means to probe nanoscale mechanical properties, which would vary with nanosheet composition and number of layers. These results pave the way for design-guided nanosheet technology; for instance, knowledge of nanosheet crumpling and extension can allow engineers to selectively produce nanosheets either as crumpled, high-surface-area powders or as flat, coherent films.
